articles.headline: U.S. Spy Agencies Are Increasingly Convinced of Saudi Prince’s Ties to Journalist’s Disappearance
articles.snippet: American intelligence officials have growing circumstantial evidence of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s involvement in Jamal Khashoggi’s disappearance in Istanbul.
articles.abstract: American intelligence officials have growing circumstantial evidence of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s involvement in Jamal Khashoggi’s disappearance in Istanbul.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American intelligence officials are increasingly convinced that Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia is culpable in the killing of the dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi, an appraisal that poses challenges to a White House intent on maintaining a close relationship with the kingdom.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Matthew Rosenberg and Gardiner Harris

articles.headline: In Afghanistan’s Season of Crisis, ‘Words Do Not Have the Strength’
articles.snippet: Seventeen years into the war, Afghans cannot remember a time quite like this, with peril and hopelessness at every turn, and no clear way out.
articles.abstract: Seventeen years into the war, Afghans cannot remember a time quite like this, with peril and hopelessness at every turn, and no clear way out.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In the past 17 years of war and crisis in Afghanistan, no one remembers a season quite like this one, with peril and hopelessness at every turn. People here struggle for words to explain how it feels.

articles.headline: Trump Embarks on Bilateral Trade Talks to Pressure China
articles.snippet: The White House is looking to create deals with many of the nations in the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the pact the president withdrew from.
articles.abstract: The White House is looking to create deals with many of the nations in the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the pact the president withdrew from.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fresh off securing trade agreements with South Korea, Canada and Mexico, President Trump is embarking on a new plan: refashioning the Trans-Pacific Partnership to his liking through a flurry of bilateral trade deals.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Senate Truce Collapses as G.O.P. Rush to Confirm More Judges Begins Anew
articles.snippet: Last week, senators agreed to confirm one last slate of President Trump’s nominees, then recess for the midterm campaign. But on Wednesday, Republicans recommenced the judicial rush.
articles.abstract: Last week, senators agreed to confirm one last slate of President Trump’s nominees, then recess for the midterm campaign. But on Wednesday, Republicans recommenced the judicial rush.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats struck a deal last week with Republicans that saw the quick confirmation of 15 more conservative judges in exchange for a rapid flight to the campaign trail. Liberal activists were infuriated, but after the brutally divisive fight to confirm Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh, the agreement held out a promise of peace.

articles.headline: Powerful Executives Have Stepped Away From the Saudis. Not SoftBank’s.
articles.snippet: The chief executive of SoftBank, Masayoshi Son, and his ambitious Vision Fund, are deeply enmeshed with the oil-rich kingdom, which has promised to invest $45 billion.
articles.abstract: The chief executive of SoftBank, Masayoshi Son, and his ambitious Vision Fund, are deeply enmeshed with the oil-rich kingdom, which has promised to invest $45 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the disappearance and apparent killing of a dissident journalist in a Saudi Arabian consulate, some of the most powerful figures in business are distancing themselves from the kingdom. There is one prominent exception: Masayoshi Son, chief executive of the SoftBank Group.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly, Landon Thomas Jr., Andrew Ross Sorkin and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Andrew Gillum, a Florida Insider Running as a Progressive Outsider
articles.snippet: Mr. Gillum, the Democratic nominee for governor, supports higher corporate taxes and Medicare for all. He also has a lobbyist as a top adviser and, as mayor of Tallahassee, was on the payroll of a consultant.
articles.abstract: Mr. Gillum, the Democratic nominee for governor, supports higher corporate taxes and Medicare for all. He also has a lobbyist as a top adviser and, as mayor of Tallahassee, was on the payroll of a consultant.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — City Hall never did seem big enough for Andrew Gillum.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: A Conservative Group’s Closed-Door ‘Training’ of Judicial Clerks Draws Concern
articles.snippet: The conservative legal movement has long cultivated law students and young lawyers, partly to ensure a deep bench of potential judicial nominees
articles.abstract: The conservative legal movement has long cultivated law students and young lawyers, partly to ensure a deep bench of potential judicial nominees
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The closed-door “training academy” was aimed at a select group: recent law school graduates who had secured prestigious clerkships with federal judges. It was organized by the Heritage Foundation, a conservative group that has played a leading role in moving the courts to the right, and it had some unusual requirements.
